Quando para mucho mi amore de felice corazón
 Mundo paparazzi mi amore chicka ferdy parasol
 Cuesto obrigado tanta mucho que canite carousel

A hodge-podge of Spanish, Italian and Portuguese words, not really making particular sense.

“When we came to sing it, to make them different we started joking, saying ‘cuando para mucho’. We just made it up. Paul knew a few Spanish words from school, so we just strung any Spanish words that sounded vaguely like something. And of course we got ‘chicka ferdi’ – that’s a Liverpool expression; it doesn’t mean anything, just like ‘ha ha ha’. One we missed: we could have had ‘para noia’, but we forgot all about it. We used to call ourselves Los Para Noias."
- John Lennon

“Que canite” is a play on “cake and eat it”, a phrase meaning that you want to have two good things which cannot exist together.

If you want to try and make sense of something that’s not supposed to make sense, someone already “deciphered” the verse.

The lavish and opulent court of the “Sun King”, Louis XIV of France, was unprecedented in Europe.

It was a constant party, sort of like the Apple days, as chronicled , by Richard DiLello, in his book: “The Longest Cocktail Party”.

Aaah, here come the sun king
 Here come the sun king

Louis XIV, was called  “The Sun King,” a title which originated with religious worship of the “solar deities.”



Many civilizations believed the Sun was a god, and in addition to being our sustaining light, also took mortal form in kings, and supreme leaders. Even as late as the 18th Century, this belief endured, in tacit superstitious awe of kings.

 This validated the doctrine of “Divine Right of Kings”, which empowered a leader’s supreme indomitable rule through legitimacy as deity.

The Beatles had affinity for Egyptian symbols, so, I’ve always related this song as an homage to the Sun-God Ra, and Egyptian Sun-King, Horus the most enduring  messianic figure from the ancient Egyptian religion.



.
This song, which is part of a beautiful medley on Side 2 of “Abbey Road”, has the similar lyrics to Harrison’s Side 1 song, “Here Comes The Sun”, which heralds the sun returning after a depressing “Long dark lonely winter”

With only two English lyrics, other than this line,

“Everybody’s laughing, everybody’s happy”
It seems as if they are also welcoming back the sun, as the “Sun King,” to dispel a metaphoric “long, dark lonely winter” …



This would fit with the messianic feel of those days in the late 60s, when the Beatles, individually, and together were experimenting and seeking enlightenment, borrowing from other cultures.

The concept of an “Avatar” or world savior, “THE Christ”, as interpreted, was very prevalent in their Eastern religious journey.

I used the Egyptian and Hindu religions, because, the Beatles were disconnected from Christianity, at the time this was written, but, from a Christian perspective and context, it is easy to assign this meaning to the “SON KING,” the “Son” of GOD, “King of KINGS,” to return to usher in a new day.



In all great lyrical poetry, the ability to broaden the meaning to incorporate the reader/listener, is an unintentional, but, successful mark of genius.
